docs.lead_paragraph: ALL the garden books I am reading this year are colored by Sara Stein's "Noah's Garden: Restoring the Ecology of Our Own Back Yards," which tells the story of how one gardener began to realize that her neat and tidy lawn, her perennial beds full of exotic shrubs and flowers had left no place for wildlife. "Noah's Garden" has affected the way I read other books and also the way I look at plants. Now, when I am enraptured by a viburnum or a butterfly bush at the local nursery, I ask, is this one the birds and butterflies could use? Anyone prone to falling asleep in botany class might enjoy NATURAL AFFAIRS: A Botanist Looks at the Attachments Between Plants and People (225 pp., Villard, $25), by Peter Bernhardt, whose first book was the whimsical "Wily Violets and Underground Orchids." Many botanists are adventurers (after all, they get paid to tramp through savannas and jungles) but few have the storyteller's ability to take the rest of us, for example, on a journey into the sexual parts of a flower -- to find the threads of a saffron crocus (Crocus sativus, if you care), uh, fascinating.
